newsitem.title: USA: FBI investigate Columbia/HCA Ohio deal - NYT.
newsitem.headline: FBI investigate Columbia/HCA Ohio deal - NYT.

text.p: The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigations is examining agreements Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp had to acquire control of some hospitals in northeastern Ohio, the New York Times said on Tuesday.
Columbia controls several hospitals in that area, including St. John West Shore Hospital and St. Vincent Charity Hospital in Cleveland and Timken Mercy Medical Center in Canton, the paper said.
Federal agents had already interviewed several people with knowledge of these situations, the New York Times said, citing people with a knowledge of the inquiry.

The Wall Street Journal, in Monday's electronic edition, said the company was asking doctors to invest in a limited partnership run by Columbia Gulf Coast Medical Center in Panama City, Fla. It cited a confidential memorandum.

Columbia was asking doctors to contribute at least $15,000 apiece to participate in the deal and if forecasts were met, they could earn a 16.8 percent return on their investment this year, the Journal said, according to the memo.
The company was not immediately available to comment.

Shares of Columbia/HCA slid on Monday over concerns about federal investigations into the company's operations in El Paso, Texas. The company said in a statement management and employees in its El Paso facilities cooperated with federal agents who presented search warrants covering a broad range of records and documents earlier this month.
The warrants were issued March 19, and the information-gathering process was completed by March 20, the company said.
